ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This course does an excellent deep dive in various themes explaining Indian development immediately before independence and into the contemporary world. Our writing assignments all have different specifications thus allowing students to practice honing their skills in various areas.
I learned a lot about the techniques used to approach Economic History and a lot about the history of India and how it coincides with the economy.
The economic history of India, understanding a number of social, political, and economic ideas in the way that they shaped India and its economy, writing history research papers

-Lots about Indian history
-How economics intersects with other aspects of human history
-Many methodologies for incorporating other disciplines into historical knowledge
I learned about various aspects of Indian history, from the role of textiles in the Indian economy under the British Raj to the patterns of the modern Indian diaspora.

Economic history of India from around 1700 to present - covered topics like impact of English colonialism, the rise and fall of India's textile industry, gender roles in economy, effects of independence, state economic planning, internal and external labor migration, role of caste, reservation system; also learned how to plan and write a 15-20 page history paper
Overview of Indian economic history 18th century to present, organized by themes

Economic History of India (honestly, the course stays pretty true to the full syllabus). Writing papers, collaborative/critical discussion, interdisciplinary history, various historiographical methods
I truly learned so much throughout this course about the economic history of india and how to critically think like a historian. It provided me with important tools and also made me a better writer.
The ability to build upon different ideas from peers, and engage with personal interests in topics.
All of the material was new to me, so I learned a lot about the economic history of India. I also learned how to write a meaningful paper of 2-3 pages (a length I hadn't dealt with much before)

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: Genuinely interesting essay prompts. I found myself exploring such a wide variety of topics that I had not expected. Prof. Amrith is excellent too, and a good facilitator of discussion.

Weaknesses: I felt that sometimes there was too much required reading (not to the point of insanity) but enough that it often took away from the class discussion when >50% of the class obviously did not do it. I think there would have been a lot more engagement had readings been more manageable.
It was a great course. I think that it could only be improved by providing the readings earlier. Otherwise, it was a very wonderful, engaging, and accessible course.
I loved this class! The content was very interesting, and the professor did a great job of making it very engaging

Strengths
-Prof. Amrith is just fantastic. Engaging, kind, and immensely knowledgeable. He does a great job blending seminar discussion with some lecture-style delivery of background information that sets the stage
-I loved the assignments in the course, especially the two short papers. A novel and exciting way to engage with the course material
-The course is well structured, surveying a range of topics in Indian history
-A terrific cultivation of course readings. I fully intend to re-read many of them at leisure once the semester is over
Weaknesses
-None at all as far as the course is concerned. 
-If I had one suggestion, it would be that Prof. Amrith should also offer a lecture course on similar topics. Given how much more he knows about Indian history than students, it would be incredibly enriching
While the readings were all well selected and enriching, I wish there was greater variation in the medium of these assignments (ex. videos).

Strengths: Professor Amrith is a leading expert in his field, so its a privilege to get to learn from him; prof is very understanding and friendly; the opportunity to explore a topic/region of the world that is often understudied; experience planning and writing a lengthy research paper that makes a historical argument | Weaknesses: sometimes, class discussion felt a little too surface level, esp when it was obvious that not many of the students had done the readings; if more students in the class came in with a solid foundation in Indian history, then maybe students would have had a little more to bring to the table beyond the readings
Well-directed seminar discussions and nicely selected readings!

Strengths: charismatic professor, engaging material, great organization, caters to many types of learning
Weaknesses: none

Strengths: I really value how wonderfully Professor Amrith teaches this course. The incorporation of various different styles of sources was wonderful. The course was very organized and each week we had the opportunity to learn about a different aspect of India and analyze it through and economics lens.
Weaknesses: None really!

The strength of this course is that it allows for a lot of independence and leeway to explore personal interests in various topics. It is very student oriented.

A weakness is that when discussions would fade out, the professor took charge of the class a lot, this could be amended with more class readings and activities being organized to make for a more structured class schedule.

The level of assigned reading is excellent: enough to learn something from each text, but not so much that sections of the text become deprioritized/skimmed. Also, Professor Amrith is an excellent facilitator and inserts just the right amount of professorial comments in a largely student-led discussion each week.

The strengths of the course definitely lie with Prof. Amrith, who is one of the best professors I've had in the history department! He cares passionately about the material he teaches, and he is incredibly supportive and encouraging to his students. I honestly sometimes wish I got to hear more from him during class he mentioned once that he may consider making this course a lecture, and while I certainly think it should remain a seminar format, I think the class would benefit from Prof. Amrith offering some "mini-lectures" at the beginning of each session to help contextualize the readings and the topic/theme for the week.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: If I were to rename this course, I would call it An Economic History of India (dropping The). If you have any interest in understanding India in the 20th century through a lens of macro-economic drivers, then take this course. As always, with such a broad subject, I left the course feeling as though we had breezed through various topics that required more attention -- specifically India in the modern day and its acute problems of development. Nonetheless, Prof. Amrith did an excellent job dovetailing a history of various interconnected themes like migration, caste, colonialism, etc into a coherent and interesting course.

Yes, I would recommend this course. Even though I did not begin the course knowing a lot about the history of India, I was still able to follow along. Additionally, the course was amazing and addressed many captivating topics.
Yes! Professor Amrith is amazing, and all of the material covered was very interesting, and I enjoyed the discussions
Absolutely! I'd recommend this course to anyone interested in India. You don't need any sort of economics background. A great way to expand your geographical range within the history major
Yes! I would recommend this course to any student with a general interest in history, especially South Asian history.
Sure, if you are interested in the topics covered and have a solid background/foundation in contemporary Indian history; a very chill history seminar
Yes, a great history seminar!

Absolutely! Professor Amrith is amazing  interested in students work, weaves so much into the course content, flexible, and he really structures the course to facilitate learning. We get feedback on a final outline before writing the paper, which is hugely helpful. Discussions in class were great too.
Yes!!!

Yes for sure!! Prof. Amrith is a really wonderful professor. He is so kind and he makes the content so so interesting and engaging! Furthermorethe actual content of this class was so interesting, I really enjoyed it!
Yes, I would recommend this class to other students, as I believe it is very relevant to current affairs.
Yes! Good syllabus, kind professor.
Yes! It's such an interesting topic, and Prof. Amrith is a fantastic history professor

extras.title: HIST 362J 01/SAST 331 01 - The Economic History of India
